T H E STORY O F T H E PANTOMIME.
Once upon a time it is supposed that the woods of some part of England
were inhabited by wild men, u ho, /hough not
exactly the Satyrf that are read of in Heathen book*, very much resembled them in their manner*.
In one of the wood* of
JVorfolk, a crew of thexe wild creature* lived, who would not permit any person dwelling in homes and wearing
woollen
clothe* to visit them, except a cei tain cruel man, the uncle of two babe* who had lost their parent*.
Now, this man,
knowing that on the death of the babes all their property would be hi* own, resolved to make away with them.
Having
taken
the advice of hi* friends the wild men, he hired two ruffians to carry the lutv babe* into a wood and slay them theie / but whet
in the middle of it, one of the ruffians repented of what ht was about to do, and re/used to murder the children, upon which
this comrade quarrelled with him,and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill the babes got killed
himself.
The surviving ruffian then thought it best to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, living only on blackberries,
until they died of fatigue
and hunger, under a tree and in each other's arms, upon
which a flight of rebins, that the children when they lived with their parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with leaves.
While this ieicked deed wa* doing, the wild men ditcovered a bevy of nymph* gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and bst their playfellow*,
but these beautiful creatures, not liking the savage*, always ran
away whenever they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,
and because she would not love him, he shut her up m the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he
pvsesttd
enabled him to do. A young woodman, her tweetheart, who was in search of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperate
struggle ensued.
The cruel uncle having come to the wood* to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man'* part.
Hut the
Fairy of the Forest, who hod watched Ihele doings, suddenly appeared, released the nymph from the tree, changed her and
her lever, the young woodmin, into Harlequin and Columbine, the uncle, for his cruelty, into P a n t a l o o n , and the wild man
into Clown. When these transformations
occurred, a variety of adventures
beftl them, scarcely to be believed, but
which new can be witnessed at the Haymarket
Theatre, every night.

FANNY
Miss

Clown,

the Year.

THE

STORY

O FT H E PANTOMIME.

Oafe up an a time it it supposed that the wood* of tome part of England
were inhabited by wild men, who, though not
exactly the Satyr* that are read of in Heathen bookt, very much retcmbled them in their manner*.
In one of the woods of
.\~orfalk, a crew of these wild creature* lited, who would not permit any person dwelling in home* and wearing
woollen
clothe* to viHt them, except m certain cruel man, the uncle of two babe* who had lo*t their parent*.
./Vow, tkit man,
knowing that on the death of the babe* all their property would be hi* OWN, resolved to make away with them.
Having
taken
the advice of hi* friend* the wild men, he hired two ruffian* to carry the twv babe* into a wood and 'lay them there > but when
in the middle of it, one of the ruffian* repented of what he wait about to do, and refused to murder Ike children, upon which
this comrade quarrelled with him, and they fought with tward and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill the babe* got killed
himself.
The surviving ruffian then thought it best to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, living only on blackberriet,
until they died of fatigue
and hunger, under a tree and in each other'* arm*, upon
which a flight of robins, that the children when they lived with their parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with feate*. While this wicked deed was doing, the wild men diictvered a bevy of nymph* gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and be their playfellow*,
but these beautiful creature*, not liking the savages, always ran
away whenever they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met with one of the most beautiful cf the wood nymph*,
and because she would not love him, he *hut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he possessed
enabled him to do. A young woodman, her nceetheart, who wa* in it arch of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperate
struggle ensued.
The cruel uncle having come to the wood* to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man''* part.
But the
Fairy of the Fore*t, who had watched theie doing*, suddenly appeared, released the nymph from the tree, changed her and
her lover, the young woodmtn, into Harlequin and Columbine, the uncle, for his cruelty, into P a n t a l o o n , and the wild man
inlo Clown. When the** transformation*
occurred, a variety of adventures
befel them, tcarcely to be believed, but
which now can be witnessed at the Haymarket
Theatre, every night.

T H E STORY O F T H E PANTOMIME.
One*, upon a time it is supposed that the wood* of tome part of England were inhabited by wild me; who, though not
exactly the Satyr* that are read of in Heathen books, very much resembled them in their manner*. In one of the wood* of
Norfolk, a erete of these wild creature* hied who would not permit any penon dwelling in kouie* and wearing woollen
clothe* to vi*it them, except a ce> tain cruel man, the uncle of Into babe.* who had toot their parent*. JVew, thi* man,
knowing that on the death of the babe* all their property wouid be hi* own, rewired to make away with them. Having taken
the advice of kit friend* the wild men, he hired two ruffian* to carry th* twv babe* into a wood and slay them there j hut when
in the middle of it, one of the ruffian* repented of what he wa* about to do, and refuted to murder the children, upon which
thi* comrade quarreled with him, and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill the babe* got killed
kimtelf. The turvtving ruffian then thought it bett to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wandered up
end down, hvmg only on blackberriei, until they died of fatigue and hunger, under a tree and in each other'* arm*, upon
which a flight of robint, that the children when they lived with their parent* used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with teoiet. While thi* wicked deed wa* doing, the wild men discovered a bevy of nymph* gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and be their playfellow*, but these beautiful creatures, not liking the lavage*, always ran
away whenever they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,
end because she would not love him, he shut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a eertain magic power that he f>stested
enabled him to d><, A young woodman, her sweetheart, who was in ttarch of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperate
struggle ensued. The cruel uncle having come to the wood* to **H if the babe* were dead, took the wild man'* part, out the
Fairy of the Forest, who had watched thete doings, suddenly appeared, releated the nymph from the tree, changed her and

T H E STORY O F T H E P A N T O M I M E .
Once upon a time it is supposed that the woods of some, part of England
were inhabited by uild men, who, though not
exactly the Satyrs that are read of in Heathen books, very much resembled thetn in their Manners,
In one of the woods of
Norfolk,
a crew of these wild creatures / l i e d , who would not permit any person dwelling in houses and wearing
ueollen
clothes to visit them, except a certain cruel man, the uncle of two babes who had lost their parents.
Now, this man,
knowing that on the death of the babes all their property would be his own, resolved to make away with them.
Having taken
the advice of his friends the mild men, he hired two ruffians to carry the twv habes into a uood and slay them thee , but when
in the middle of U, one of the ruffians repented of what he was about to do, and refused to murder the children, upon which
this comrade quarrelled with kirn, and they fought with sword and dagqer, until the man who u anted to kill Hie babes got killed
himself.
The surviving ruffian then thought tl best to leave the children in the wood, which he didf where they wandered up
and down, living only on blackberries,
until they died of fatigue and hunger, under a tree end tn each other's arms, upon
which a flight of robins, that the children when they lived with their parents lined to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with leaves.
While this tricked deed was doing, the wild men discovered a bevy of nymphs gathering blaekberriett in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and bt their playfellows,
but these beautiful cmaiure*, not liking the savages, always ran.
away whenever they saw them, until one dag, the chief of the wild men met with on* of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,
and because she would not love him, he shut her up in the trunk of a targe oak, which a certain magic power that he pwnetsed
enabled him to do. A young woodman, her sweetheart, who was in starch of her, encountered the wild man. when a desperate
struggle ensued.
The cruel uncle having come to the wood* to see if the babes were dead, look the wild man % part,
llat the
fairy of the Forest, who had watched these doings, suddenly appeared, released the nymph from the tree, changed her and
her lover, th* young woodman, into Harlequin and Columbine, the uncle, for his ciueltg, into Pantaloon, and the w.td man
into Clown. When these transformation*
occurred, a variety of adventures
befel them, tcureely
to be believed, but
which now can be witnessed at the Haymatket
Theatre, every night.

T H E STORY O F T H E P A N T O M I M E .
Once upon a time it is supposed that Che woods of to-ne part of England
were inhabited by uild men, who, though riot
exactly the Satyrs that are read of in Heathen bookt, very much resembled them in their manners.
In one of the wood* of
Norfolk,
a crew of these wild creatures /it erf, who would not permit any person dwelling in houses and wearing
uoulien
clothes to visit them, except a certain cruel man, the uncle of two babes who had lost their parents.
A'ow, this man,
knowing that on the death of the bobes all their property would be his own, resolved to make away with them.
Having taken
the advice of his friends the wild men, he hired two ruffians to carry the twv babes into a wood and slay them thei e ; but when
in the middle of it, one of the ruffians repented of what he was about to do, and refused to murder the children, upon which
this comrade quarrelled with him, and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill the babes got killed
himself.
The surviving ruffian then thought it best to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wander ei up
and down, living only en blackberries,
until they died of fatigue
and hunger, under a tree and in each other's arms, upon
which a flight of robins, that the children when they lived with thetr parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with leaves.
While this wicked deed was doing, the wUd men discovered a bevy of nymphs gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and be their playfellows,
but these beautiful creatures, not liking the savages, always ran
away whenever they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,,
and because she would not love him, he shut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he poieessed
enabled him to do. A young woodman, her sweetheart, who was m search of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperatestruggle ensued.
The cruel uncle having come to the woods to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man $ part.
But the
Fairy of the Forest, who had watched these doings, suddenly appeared, released the nymph from the tree, changed her and
her lover, the young woodmnn, into Harlequin and Columbine, the uncle, for his cruelty, into P . n t a l o . n , and the w.id man
into Clown. When these transformation*
occurred,*
variety of adventures
heft I them, scarcely to be believed, but
which now can be witnessed at the Haymmrket
Theatre, every night.

T H E STORY

<-B..l

T h e London Holidays throughout t h e Year. 1

[An attempt ha. be«n made to attach a little antiquarian ir.t-r*«t to the Overtmv, for in addition to the many popular " liouachoWl " tunes introduced wdl bo
found th. original air of "The Children in the Wood," oompo.ed in the reien of Queen Elizabeth, br.ides mi oral real old Cbrintmaa Oaroli, including the
" Hoar', Head," ,ung annually on Christmas Day at Queen'. College, Oiford.]
'I he Ma.ic of the Harlequinade Composed and Arranged by M R .
SPILLANE.
The
Story written
Pantomime,,
The Opening
Opening Story
written by
t>y the
me Author
ABtnor of
oi the
uir popular
uupum, Hnymarket
„n}„

Once upon a time it is supposed that the woodi of tome part, of lingland
were inhabited by uild men, who, though not
exactly the Satyrs that are read of in Heathen hooks, rery much resembled them in their manners.
In one of the woods of
Norfolk,
a crew of these wild creatures lived, who would not permit any person dwelling in houses and wearing
voollen
clothes to visit them, except a certain cruel man, the uncle of two babes who had lost their parent*.
Now, this man,
knowing that on the death of the babes all their property would be his own, resolved to make away with them.
Hat ing taken
the advice of his friends the wild men, he hired two ruffians to carry the Iwv babes into a wood and slay them thee • but when
in the middle of it, one of the ruffians repented of what he was about to do, and refused to murder the children, upon which
this comrade quarrelled with him, and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill the babes got killed
himself.
The surviving ruffian then thought xt best to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, living only en blackberries,
until they died of fatigue
and hunger, under a tree and in each other's arms,
upon
which a flight of rebtns, that the children when they lived with their parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with leaves.
While this wicked deed was doing, the wild men discovered a bevy of nymphs gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and be their playfellows,
but these beautiful creatures,
not liking the savages, always ran
away whenever they taw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,
rnnd bee awe. she would not love him, he shut her up \n the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he po'tested
tumbled him to do. A young woodman, her sweetheart, who was in search of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperate
struggle ensued.
The cruel uncle having come to the woods to see if the babes were dead, look the wild man's part,
tint the
Fairy of the Forest, who had watched these doing*, suddenly appeared,
released the nymph from the tree, changed her and
her lover, the young woodman, into Harlequin and C o l u m b i n e , the uncle, for his cruelty, into Pantaloon, and the wild man
into Clown.
When these transformations
occurred,m
variety of advtntures
befel them, scarcely to be believed, but
which now can be witnessed at the Haymmrket
Theatre, every
night.

THE OLD HOUSE AT HOME.

COWEIATHE flEDINA WATRRH,

B

Once upon a time it in supposed thai the wood* of sow part of England
were inhabited by uild men, who, though not
exactly the Satyrs that are read of in Heathen baokt, very much resembled them in their manner*.
In one of the woods of
JVorfolk, a crew of these wild creature* lived, who would not. permit any pernon dwelling in heuie* and wearing
woollen
clothe* to vi*U them, except a certain cruel man, the uncle of two babe* who had lott their parent*.
JS'ott, this man,
knowing that on the death of the babe* all their property woulct be hi* own, resolved to make away with them.
Mating
taken
the advice of ht* friend* the wild men, he hired two ruffian* to carry the twv babe* into a wood and flay them theie ,• but whet
in the middle of it, one of the ruffian* repented of what he was about to do, and refuted to murder the children, upon which
this comrade quarrelled with him, and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill the babes got killed
himself.
The surviving ruffian then thought tt best to leave the children in the, wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, living only on blackberries,
until they died of fatigue
and hunger, under a tree and in each other's arms, upon
which a flight of rebint, that the children when they lived with their parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and coveredthem with leave*,
While thi* wicked deed was doing, the. wild men ditcovered a bevy of nymph* gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and h* their playfellows,
but the** beautiful cieatures,
not liking the'savages, always ran
away whenever they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met. with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymph*,
rnnd because she would not love him, he shut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he possested
enabled him to do. A young wocximan, her sweetheart, who was in tearch of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperate
struggle ensued.
The cruel uncle having come to the woods to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man* part.
But the
Fairy of the Forest, who hod watched these doings, suddenly appeared, released Ike nymph from the tree, changed her an<t
her lover, the young woodman, into Harlequin and C o l u m b i n e , the uncle, for his cruelty, into Pantaloon, and the wdd man
into Clown. When these transfermations
occurred, a variety of adventures
befel them, uarte/y
to be believed, but
which now can be wilnttsed at the Jfaymarket
Theatre, every night.

THE STORY O FT H E PANTOMIME.
Once upon a time it is supposed (hat the woods of tome part of England
were inhabited by uild men, who, though not
exactly the Satyr* that are read of in Heathen books, very much resembled them in their manners.
In one of the woods of
Norfolk,
a crew of these wild creatures lited, who would not permit any person dwelling in houses and wearing
woollen
clothe* to visit them, except a certain cruel man, the uncle of two babes who had lost their parents,
JYOW, this man,
knowing that on the death of the babe* all their property would be his own, resolved to make away with them.
Having taken
the advice of his friend* the wild men, he hired two ruffians to carry th* lutv babe* into a wood and ilny them there; but when.
in the middle of it, one of the ruffians repented of what he was about to do, and refuted to murder the children, upon which
thi* comrade quarrelled with him, and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill the babes got killed
himself.
The surviving ruffian then thought. \t best to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, living only on blackberries,
until they died of fatigue
and hunger, under a tree and in each other* arms-, upon
which a flight of robins, that the children when ihey lived with their parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them With leaves.
While this wicked deed was doing, the wild men discovered a bevy of nymph* gathering blackberries in the
•wood, whom they wanted to come and hi their playfellows,
but these beautiful a natures, not liking the savages, always ran
away whenever they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,
mnd because she would not love him, he thui her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he possessed
enabled him to do. A young woodman, her twee.theart, who wa* in search of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperate
struggle ensued.
The cruel uncle having come to the woods to see if the babe* were dead, look the wild man's part.
But the
Fairy of the Forest, who had watched these doings, suddenly appeared, released the nymph front the tree, changed her and
her lover, the young woodman, into Harlequin and C o l u m b i n e , the uncle, for his cruelty, into P a n t a l o o n , and the wild man
into Clown. When theie tran*f»rtnatton*
occurred, a variety of adventures
befel them, nmrcefy to be believed, but
which now can be witnessed at the Haymarket
Theatre, every night.

T H E STORY O F T H E P A N T O M I M E .
Once upon a lime it is supposed that the woods of some part of Rngland
were hihaliUd tig mid men, wha, though not
exactly the Satyr* that are read of in Heathen books, very much resembled them in their manners.
In one . / the woods of
Norfolk,
a crew of these wild creatures Hied tchu would not permit any person duelling in houses and treating
ui,alien
clothes to visit them, except a ce tain cruel man, the uncle of two babes who had lost their parents.
A'ow, tnis man,
knowing that on the death of the bribes all their property uoul I lie his on n, re ulred to make away with them.
lia\ uig taken
the advice of his friends the uild men, he hired tuo ruffian* to carry the twr babes into a wo< d and slay them the e • but when
in the middle of it, one of the ruffians repeuUd of u/iat he was about to do. and refused to murder the chilhe'i,
it/mi which
this comrade quartet ed with him, and thev fought with tword and dagger, until the man who u anted to kill the babes got killed
himself.
The surviving ruffian then thought it best to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where theg wandered up
and down, living only on blackberries,
uidd they died of fatigue
and hunger, under a tree and in each other s arms, upon
ii hich a flight of robin*., that the children when they lived with then parents u>cd to feed, came out of gratitude, and coveredthem with leaves.
" lule this wnked deed was doing, the. wild men discovered a bevy etf nymphs gathering htackt/eiries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and ht their playfellows,
but the.w beautiful eieitvres,
not liking the savages, always ran
away whenever they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wtbl men mrl with one of the most beautiful of the wood m/mphs,
and because she would not love him, he shut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that l.e po seised
enabled him to do. A young woodman, her sucelheart, who n as in sun ch of her, encountered the wild man_ when a dtsperate
stivggle ensued.
The cruel uncle having come to the woods to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man' i part.
Hut the
hairy of tt.c Forest, who had wutchtd these doings, suddenly appeared, rtleastd the nymph friin the tree, changed her and
her lover, the young woodmin, into Harlequin and Columbine, the uncle, for his ciuelti/, into Pantaloon, and the u.ld man
into Clown. When these transf»imotions
occurred, a variety of adventures
befi them, tcurctly to be believed, but
which now can be witnessed at the Hat/market
Theatre, every night.

M APOTHEOSIS OF THE BABES 11 THE WOOD.
T H EH A R L E Q U I N A D E

PANTOMIME.

Once upon a lime it in supposed that (he wood* of some part of England
uere inhabited by uild men, u An, though not
exactly the Satyr* that are read of in Heathen books, very much resembled them in their manner*.
In line of the woods of
Norfolk,
a crew of these uild creature* lued
who would not permit any prison dwelling in houses and wearing
uoollen
clothes to visit them, except a ce* tain cruel man, the uncle of two babes who had tost their parents.
A'ow. this man,
knowing that on the death of the babe* all their property woitLi be his own, reolved to make away with them.
Hating
taken
the advice of his friends the wild men, he hired too ruffians to carry the Iter babes into a woi d and * lay them the e < but whet
in the middle of it, one of the ruffians repented of uhal he was about to do, and refused to murder the chilire<\, ttpon which
this comrade quarrel cd with him, and they fought with ../.,;./ and dagger, umil the man who u ailed to kilt the ha ben got killed
himself.
The surviving »ujffian the* thought it best to leave the children m the w>od, which he did, where theg wandered np
and down, living only on blackberries,
until they died of fatigue and hunger, under a tree and in eaih other s arms, upon
which a flight of robins, that the cbi/dren when they lived with their parents used to feed, came out if gratitude, and coveredthem with leaves,
It title this i»«< ked deed an* doing, the wild men discovered a bevy nf nymphs gathering blackbsiries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and bit their playfellows,
hut thete beautiful eie ttures, not liking the savages, always ran
away whenever llwy saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men nut with one of the most beautiful of the wood w/mphs,
and because she would not love him, he shut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which, a certain magic power that he po setsed
enabled him to do. A young woodman, her sweetheart, who was m starch of her, encountered the wild man, when a dtsperate
Hingijle ensued.
The cruel wide having come to the wood* to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man <r part,
but the
fairy of the Forest, who had watched these doing*, suddenly appeared, releastd the nymph frim the tree, changed her and
her lover, the young woodrnin, into Harlequin and Coltimbine, the uncle, for his ciuelln, into I'.i.taloi-ti, and the w.ld man
into Clown.
When these transformations
occurred, a variety of adventures
befl ihcrn, icurcttg to be believed, but
which now can be witnessed at the Haumarket
Theatre, every night.

this comrade quart el'ed with him, and they fought with word and dagger, until the man uho u ii'iterl to kill the babe* got killed
himself.
The surviving ruffian then thought it btst to leave the children in Vie wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, living only on bluchbemes,
until they died of fatigue and hti>ger, Under a tree and in each other s arms, upon
which a flight of robin*, that the children when they lived wth their parents used to feed came out of gratitude, and covered
them with leaves.
It hile this wicked deed was doing, the wild men discovered a bevy of nymphs gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wonted to come and ba their /ilai/letlowi,
but these beautiful cieitures,
not liking the savages, alicays ran
away whenever theti sail fiem, until one day, the chief of the wiltl men met with one of I lie most beautiful if fie wood nymphs,
mud bee awe she would riot love him, he shut her up m the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he possessed
enabled Mm to do A x,oni<y woodman her sweetheart, who was in si arch of her, encountered the wild man when a desperate
struggle ensued.

fairy of tie Forest, who hull initched thtte doings, suddenly appeared, released the nymph from the tree, changed her and

THE STORY O F T H E PANTOMIME.
Once upon a time it is supposed that the woods of some part of England were inhabited by uiid tnefi, who, though not
exactly the Satyrs that are read of in Heathen books, N N much resembled them in their manners.
In one of the woods of
Norfolk, a crew of these wild creatures lived, who would not permit any person dwelling in houses and wearing woollen
clothes to visit them, except a cet tain cruel man, the uncle of two babes who had lost their parents. Now, this man,
knowing that on the death of the babes all their property would he his own, revolted to make away with them. Having taken
the advice of his friends the wild men, he hired two ruffians to carry the twv tabes into a wood and slay them theic t but when
in the middle of it, one of the ruffians repented of what he was about to do, and refused to murder the children, upon which
this comrade quarrelled with him, and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill ike babes got killed
himself. The surviving , vffian then thought it best to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, living only on blackberries, until they died of fatigue and huvger, under a tree and in each other's arms, upon
which a flight of robins, that the children when they lived with their parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with leaves. It hile this wicked deed was doing, the wild men discovered a bevy of nymphs gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and be their playfellows, but thefe beautiful rieatures, not liking the savages, always ran
away whenever theii saw them, until one day, the chief of the will men met with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,
and because she would not lore him, he shut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he porse*sed
enabled him to do. A youvg woodman, her sweetheart, who was in search of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperate,
struggle ensued. The auel uncle having come to the woodi to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man't part. But the
fairy of the Forest, who had watched thete doings, suddenly appeared, released the nymph from the tree, changed her anil
her lover, the young woodmin, into Harlequin and Columbine, the uncle, for his cruelty, into Pantaloon, and the wild man
into Clown. When these transformations occurred, a variety of adventures befl them, icurcely to be believed, but
which now can be witnessed at tlie Haymarket Theatre, every night.

T H E STORY

CAL.I.-COTT.

OF T H E PANTOMIME.

Once upon a time it is supposed that the woods of some patl of England were inhabited by uild men, who, though not
exactly the Satyr* that are read of in Heathen books, very much resembled them in their manners. In one of the woods of
Norfolk, a crew of these wild creatures hied, who would not permit any person dwelling in houses and wearing woollen
clothe* to visit them, except a ret tain cruel man, the uncle of two babes who had lost their parents. Now, this man,
knowing that on the death of the babes all their property would be his own. re olved to make away with them. Having taken
the advice of his friends the wild men, he hired two ruffian* to carry the twv babes into a wood and slay them thei* ; but when
in the middle of it, one of the ruffian* repented of what he was about to do, and refused to murder the children, upon which
this comrade quarielled with him, and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill the babes got killed
himself. The surviving luffian then thought it best to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, living only on blackberries, until they died of fatigue and hunger, under a tree and in each other'* arm*, upon
which a flight of robins, that the children when they lived with their parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with leave*. H hile this wicked deed was doing, the wild men discovered a bevy of nymphs gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and be their playfellow*, but these beautiful erealures, not liking the savages, always ran
away whenever they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,
mnd betatue she would not love him, he shut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he possessed
enabled him to do. A young woodman, her sweetheart, who wa* in tearch of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperate
struggle ensued. The cruel uncle having come to the moods to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man\ part. But the
fairy of the Forest, who had watched these doings, suddenly appeared, released the nymph from the tree, changed htr and
her lover, the young woodman, into Harlequin and Columbine, the uncle, for his cruelty, into Pantaloon, and the wild man
into Clown. When these transformation* occurred,a variety of adventure* bejel thtm, iemrcely to be belkved, but
jtjiich now can be witnessed at the Hayme,rkel Theatre, every night.

M GRAND P A S

Once upon a lime it is supposed that the woods of some part of England
were inhabited by uild men, who, though not
exactly the Satyrs that are read of in Heathen hooka, very much resembled them in their manners.
In one of the woods of
•Norfolk, a crew of these wild creatures hied, who uould not permit any person dwelling in houses and wearing
woollen
clothes to visit them, except a certain cruel man, the uncle of two babes uho had tost their parents.
Now, this man,
knowing that on the death of the babes all their property would be his own, resolved to make away with them.
Having
taken
the advice of his friends the wild men, he hired two ruffians to carry the iwv babes into a wot,d and slay them theie ; but when
in the middle of it, one of the ruffians repented of uhat he was about to do, and refused to murder the children, upon which
this comrade yuan el ed with him, and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who u anted to kill the babes got killed
himself.
The sunning
ruffian then thought it btst to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, living only on blackberries,
until they died of fatigue
and hunger, under a tree and in each other's arms, upon
which a flight of robins, that the children when they lived with their parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with leaies.
H hile this wicked deed was doing, the wild men discovered a bevy of nymphs gathering blackberries in the
wood, whom they wanted to come and be their playfellows,
but these beautiful ci eatures, not liking the savages, always ran
mray whenirer they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,
ei d heave
she would not lore him, he shut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he M ' M M M
enabled lum to do. A yoiivg woodman, her sweetheart, who was in search of her, encountered the wild man, whena
desperate
tit uyi^ It er.nied.
The ci itel uncle having come to the wood* to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man's part.
But the
fairy 0/ / / 1 Forest, 11 ho had watched these doings, suddenly appeared, released the nymph from the tree, changed her and
her /, rer, the young woodman, into Harlequin and Columbine, Me uncle, for his cruelty, into P a n t a l o o n , and the wild man
:vto (Jlo«n.
When these transformations
occurred,a
variety of adventures
befel them, scarcely to be believed, but
vhich now can be witnessed at the JIaymurket
Theatre, every night.

The Pursuit of Lucibel by Hornyhoof— His Revenge at her Disdain.

New Year,

Once upon a time it is supposed that the woods of i w c part of England were inhalited by uild men, who, thouuA not
exactly the Satyrs thai are read of in Heathen icon's, very much resembled them in their manners.
In one of the woods of
JVwfolk, a crew of these wild treatures hied, uho 1/unlit not permit any person dwelling in houses and wearing uoollen
clothes to visit them, except a cet tain cruel man, the uncle of two babes who had lost their parents. •JVOW. this man,
knowing that on the death of the babes all their property would be his own, resolved to make away with them. Hat tug taken
the advice of his friends the wild men, he hired two ruffians to carry the iwv babes into a wood and slay them thei e ; but when
in the middle of it, one of the tuffians repented of what he uas about to do, and re/used to murder the children, upon which
this comrade quarteUed with him, and they fought with sword and dagger, until the man who wanted to kill the babes got killed
himself. The surviving , iiffinn then thought it best to leave the children in the wood, which he did, where they wandered up
and down, Itvtng only on blackberries, until they died of Jattgue and hunger, under a tree and in each other's arms, upon
whtch a /fight of tubins, that the children when they lived with their parents used to feed, came out of gratitude, and covered
them with leaves. H htle this wicked deed tint doing, the wild men discovered a bevy of nymphs gathering blackberries in the
Wood, whom they wanted to come and be their playfellows, but these beautiful treatures, not liking the savages, always ran
away whenever they saw them, until one day, the chief of the wild men met with one of the most beautiful of the wood nymphs,
mnd because she would not lore him, he shut her up in the trunk of a large oak, which a certain magic power that he possessed
enabled Aim to do. A young woodman, her sweetheart, who was in search of her, encountered the wild man, when a desperate
struggle ensued. The cruel uncle having come to the woods to see if the babes were dead, took the wild man's part. But the
fairy of the Forest, uho had watched these doings, suddenly appeared, released the nymph from the tree, changed her and
her lover, the young woodman, into Harlequin and Columbine, the uncle, for his cruelty, into Pantaloon, and the wild man
into Clown. When these transformations occurred, a variety of adventures befel them, scarcely to be believed, but
which now can be witnessed at the Haymarket Theatre, every night.

that Comedy by t h e HAY MARKET COMPANY, having gained t h e
approbation or Crowded Houses, It will he repeated
T h i s Evening. M O N D A Y , Sept. 1 4 t h , T U E S D A Y , Sept. l S t h ,
and W E D N E S D A Y , Sept. 1 6 t h .

and S A T U R D A Y , Sept. 1 9 t h .

Will embrace aU the Incident* of the Story of " THE SLEEPING BEAUTY »N THE WOOD." The King and Queen
that lived once, and who had been married many year* without having any children—the beautiful Baby that wa* at last
born to them—the Imitation to all the Fairie* to *tand Godmother* to the Prince** at her Christening—the unfortunate
omission of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old Fairy, who wa* mypated to be dead, or under the influence of some spell—
the good Gift* given to the young Prince** by Seven of her Fairy Godmother*—Si arrival of the Spiteful Fairy, who throw*
the whole Court into dismay, by declaring that when the Princes* grew to be m young woman *he would prick her hand with
a spindle, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly hairy, the principal Godmother, that she would so arrange
the matter that the Princess should not hie, when wounded by the spindle, but only sleep a Hundred Year*, when a King's
Son would come and wake her—the Proclamation issued by the King, abolishing the use of spindles throughout the land—
the growing up of the Prince** till she was sixteen—Aer arrival with her Parent* and the Court at a Summer Palace—her
slipping away from tutm, and finding an old woman *pinning~ her trying to spin herself -her wounding her hand, mt forttold, and JaUing atleep for a Hundred i ear*— the friendly Fairy causing a Wood to grow up, and enclose the Palace, and
the Princes* sleeping for a Century ; and with her, to keep her companu, all the Maid* of Honour, Gentlemen, Officers,
Stewards, Cooks, Scullions, Ilmnnttig Footmen, Guards, Porter*, Pages, and Valets—the passing away of the One Hundred
Year*, and a young Prince finding out, the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating into the Palace—his waking the Sleeping
Beauty, and ait her Attendants—the Princess and the Prince falling mutually in lore at first sight, with the interference of
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who vow* to do Iter worst to dtstriy their happiness—the arrival of one of the Fairy Godmothers of
the Princess to protect her—the constancy of the Prince being tried by the friendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all htr art* and graces to turn him (rom the Princess—the Prince becoming Harlequin, and the Princess following him
through the world— the Spiteful Old Fairy's resolve that the Prince and Princess shall not escape her, she changing herself
into Pantaloon, and one of her Familiar* into Clown—with the final liiumph of the I'rmce and I'rince**, who are made
happy by the Friendly Fairy.

Will embrace all the Incidents of the Story of " T H E S L R E P I N O B E A U T Y IN T H E W O O D . "
The King and QueeM
that lived once, and who had been married many years without having any children—the
beautiful Baby that teas at last
born to them—the Imitation
to all the Fairies to stand Godmothers to the Princess at h?r Christening—the
unfortunate
omission of neglecting to invite a Spiteful
Old Fairy, who was supposed to be dead, or under the influence of tome spel\-m
the good Gifts given to the young Princess by Seven of her Fairy Godmothers—the
arrival of the Spiteful Fairy, who throwt
the whole Court into dismay, by declaring that when the Princess grew to be a young woman she would prick her hand with
a spindle, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly
fairy,
the principal
Godmother,
that she would so arrange
the matter that the Princes* should not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only deep a Hundred
Years, when a King's
Son wouldtcome and wake her—the Proclamation
issued by the King, abolishing
the use of spindles throughout the land—4
the growing up of the Princess till she was sixteen—her arrival with her Parents and the Court at a Summer
Palace—her
slipping away from them, and finding an old woman spinning— her trying to spin herself -her wounding her hand,
as/ore^
tola, and falling asleep for a Hundred Years—the friendly Fairy causing a Wood to grow up, and enclose the Palace, and
the Princess sleeping for a Century ; and with her, to keep her company, all the Maids of Honour, Gentlemen,
Officers,
Stewards, Covks, Sculions,
Running Footmen, Guards, Porters, Pages, and Valets—the passing away of the One Hundred
Years, and a young Prince finding out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating
into the Palace—his waking the Sleeping
Beauty, and all her Attendants—the
Princess and the Prince lolling mutually in love at first sight, with the interference of
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who vows to do her worst to dtstnv
their havpintsi—the
arrival of one of the Fairy Godmothers of
the Princess to protect her—the constancy of the Prince being tried by the friendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all her arts and graces to turn him from the Princess—the
Prince berominu Harlequin, and the Princess following him
through the uorld— the Spiteful Vld Fairy's resolve that the Prince and Princess shall not escape her, she changing
herself
into Pantaloon,
and one of her Familiars
into Clown—uith
the final triumph of the Prince and Princess,
who are matte
happy by the Friendly
Fairy.

Hill emb, ace all the Incident* of the Sto<y of " T H E SLEEPING BEAUTY IN THE WOOD." The King and Queen
thmt lived once, and who had keen married many year* without hating any (htldren—the beautiful Baby that wat at la*t
born to them—the Invitation to all the Fairiet to ttand Godmother* to the Prince** at her Christening—the unfortunate
emission of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old Fairy, who woe guppoted to be dead or under the influence of tome spell—
the good Gift* given to the young Prince** by Seven of her Fairy Godmother*—the arrival of the Spiteful Fairy, who throw*
the whole Court into ditmay, by declaring that when the Prince** grew to be a young woman *he would prick her hand with
a spindle, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly fairy, the principal Godmother, that the would to arrange
the matter that the Prince** thould not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only deep a Hundred Year*, when a k'tng't
Son would come and wake her-—the Proclamation issued by the King, abolishing the me of spindle* throughout the land—
the growing up of the Prince** till she wa* sixteen—her arrival with her Parent* and the Court at a Summer Palace—her
slipping awau from them, and finding an old woman spinning — her trying to spin herself -her wounding her hand, at foretold, and falling atleep for a Hundred Year*—the friendly Fairy causing a Wood to grow up, and enclote the Palace, and
the Princess sleeping for a Century ; and with her, to keep her company, all the Maid* of Honour, Gentlemen, Officer*,
Stewards, Cooks, Scullion*, Running Footmen, Guard*, Porter*, Page*, and Valet*—-the patting away of the One Hundred
Year*, and a young Prince finding out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating into the Palace—hi* waking the Sleeping

all her art* and grace* to turn him from the Prince**-—the Prince becoming Harlequin, and the Princess following him
through the world— the Spiteful Old Fairy* leiolve that the Prince and Princes* thai! not escape her, the changing herself
into Pantaloon, and one of her Familiars into Cloun—with the final triumph of the Prince and Prince**, who are made

Will embrace all the Incident* of the Story of " T H E SLEEPING BEAUTY IN T H E WOOD." The King and Queen
that lived once, and who had been married many year* without having any children—(he beautiful Baby that was at latt
born to them—the Invitation to all the Fairie* to *tand Godmother* to the Prince** at her Christening—the
unfortunate
omission of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old Fairy, who wae *upposed to be dead, or under the influence of tome spell—
the good Gift* given to the young Prince** by Seven of her Fairy Godmother*—the arrival of the Spiteful Fairy, who throw*
the whole Court into ditmay, by declaring that when the Prince** grew to be a young woman the would prick her hand with
a spindle, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly hairy, the principal Godmother, that the would to arrange
the matter that the Prince** ihould not die, when wounded by the tpindle, but only tleep a Hundred Fear*, when a King'*
Son would come and wake her—the Proclamation ietued by the King, abolishing the use of tpindle* throughout the land—'
the growing up of the Prince** till the wa* sixteen—her arrival with her Parent* and the Court at a Summer Palace—her
dipping away from them, and finding an old woman tpinning—her trying to spin hertelf -her wounding her hand, as foretold, and falling atleep for a Hundred Year*—the friendly Fairy canting a Wood to grow up, and enclose the Palace, and
the Princes* *leeping for a Century ; and with her, to keep her company, alt the Maid* of Honour, Gentlemen, Officer*,
Steward*, Cooks, Scullion*, Running Footmen, Guard*, Porter*, Page*, and Valet*—the patting away of the One Hundred
Year*, and a young Prince finding out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating into the Palace—AM waking the Sleeping
Beauty, and all her Attendant*—the Prince** and the Prince falling mutually in love atfirtt tight, with the interference of
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who vowt to do her worst to dettroy their happtntts—the arrival of one of the Fairy Godmothert of
the Prince** to protect her—the constancy of the Prince being tried by the friendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all her art* and grace* to turn him from the Prince**—the Prince becoming Harlequin, and the Prince** following him
through the world— the Spiteful Old Fairy* resolve that the Prince and Princes* thalt not etcape her, the changing hertelf
into Pantaloon, and one of her Familiars into Clown—with the final ttiumph of the l*rince and Prince**, who are made
happy by the Friendly Fairy.

T H E DANCES ARRANGED AND THR WHOLE PRODUCED UNDER T H E DIRECTION OF

Mr.

L E C L E R C Q[ .m R B B .

Will embrace all the Incident* of the Story of " T H E S L E E P I N G B E A U T Y I N T H E W O O D . "
The King and Queen
that lived once, and who had been married many years without having any children—the
beautiful Baby that was at last
born to them—<Ae Invitation to all the Fairies to stand Godmothers to the Princess at her Christening—the
unfortunate
omission of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old Fairy, who was supposed to be dead, or under the influence of some spell-*
the good Gifts given to the young Princess by Seven of her Fairy Godmothers—the
arrival of the Spiteful Fairy, who throw*
the whole Court into dismay, by declaring that when the Princess grew to be a young woman the would prick her hand with
a spindle, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly
hairy, the principal
Godmother, that she would so arrange
the matter that the Princess should not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only »leep a Hundred
Years, when a King'-,
Son would come and wake her—.the Proclamation
issued by the King, abolishing the use of spindles throughout the land—
the growing up of the Princess till she was sixteen—her
arrival with her Parents and the Court at a Summer
Palace—her
slipping away from them, and finding an old woman spinning—her
trying to spin herself -her wounding her hand, as fvetolet, and falling asleep for a Hundred Fears—the friendly Fairy causing a Wood to grow up and enclose the Palace, and
the Princess sleeping for a Century;
and with her, to keep her company, all the Maids of Honour, Gentlemen,
Officers,
Stewards, Cooks, Scullions, Running Footmen, Guards, Porters, Pages, and Valets—the passing away of the One Hundred
fears, and a young Prince fading out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating
into the Palace—A»* waking the Sleeping
Beauty, and all her Attendants—the
Princess and the Prince falling mutually in love at first sight, with the interference of
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who vows to do her worst to destroy their hattpmtss—the
arrival of one of the Fairy Godmothers of
the Princess to protect her—the constancy of the Prince being tried by the friendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all her arts and graces to turn him from the Princess—the
Prince becoming Harlequin,
and the Princess following him
through the world— the Spiteful Old Fairy's resolve that the Prince and Princets shall not escape her, she changing
herself
into Pantaloon,
and one of her Familiars
into Clown—with the final triumph of the J'rince and Princess, who are made
happy by the Friendly
Fairy,

WALES.

S I B ensbrace all the Incident* of the Story of " THE 8LEEP1NG BEAUTY IN T H E WOOD." The King and Queen
that lived onee, and who had been married many year* without having any children—the beautiful Baby that tea* at lait
born to them—the Invitation to all the Fairie* to stand Godmother* to the Prince** at her Christening—the unfortunate
omittion of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old Fairy, who was supposed to be dead, or under the influence of some *pell—m
the good Gift* givtn to the young Prince** by Seven of her Fairy Godmothers—the arrival of the Spiteful Fairy, who throw*
the whole Court into dismay, by declaring that when the Princess grew to be a young woman she would prich her hand with
a spindle, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly Fairy, the principal Godmother, that the would to arrange
the matter that the Princets should not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only sleep a Hundred Yeart, when a King's
Son would come and wake her—the Proclamation issued by the King, abolishing the use of spindles throughout the land—
the growing up of the Princess till she was sixteen—Aer arrival with her Parents and the Court at a Summer Palace—her
slipping away from them, and finding an old woman spinning—her trying to spin herself -her wounding her hand, as fort*
tola, and fading asleep for a Hundred fears—the friendly Fairy causing a (rood to grow up and enclose the Palace, and
the Princess sleeping for a Century ; and with her, to keep her company, all the Maids of Honour, Gentlemen, Officers,
Stewards, Cooks, Scullions, Running Footmen, Guards, Porters, Pages, and Valets—the passing away of the One Hundred
Yeart, and a young Prince finding out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating into the Palace—his waking the Sleeping
Beauty, and all her Attendants—the Princess and the Prince falling mutually in love at first night, with the interference of
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who vows to do her worst to dtstny their hamtntts—the arrival of one of the Fairy Godmothers of
the Princess to protect her—the constancy of the Prince being tried by the friendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all her arts ana graces to turn him from the Princes*—the Prince betoming Harlequin, and the Princess followi** him
through the world— the Spiteful Old Fairy's resolve that the Prince and Princets shall not escape her, she changing herself
into Pantaloon, and one of her Familiars into Chun—ari'A the final triumph of the Prince and Princess, who are made
happy by the Friendly Fairy,

' S I S embrace all the Incidents of the Story of " T H E S L F E P I N O B E A U T Y IN T H E W O O D . "
The King and Q«ee*
that lived once, and who had been married many years without having any children—the
beautiful Baby that mat at latt
born to them—the Invitation to all the Fairiet to stand Godmothers to the Princest at htr Christening—the
unfortunate
omission of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old Fairy, who wet supposed U, be dead, or under the influence of tome spell-m
Jhe good Gift* given'to the young Princess by Seven of her Fairy Godmothers—the
antral of the Spiteful Fairy, who ihrowt
the whole Court into dismay, by declaring that when the Princess grew to be a young woman the would prick her hand with
•a tpindte, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly I-airy, the principal
Godmother, that she would so arrange
the matter that the Princess should not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only *letp a Hundred
Fears, when a King's
JSon would come and wake her—the Proclamation
itsued by the King, abolishing the use of spindles throughout the land—
the growing up of the Princess till she was sixteen—her
arrival with htr Parents and the Court at a Summer
Palace—her
flipping
away from them, and finding an old woman spinning—her
trying to spin herself -her wounding her hand, at foretola, and fading
asleep for a Hundred Years—the friendly Fairy causing a Hood to grow up, and enclose the Palace, ana
the Princess sleeping for a Century .- and uith her, to keep her company, all the Maidt of Honour, Gentlemen,
Officers,
Stewards, Cooks, ScuUions, Funning Footmen, Guards, PorUrt, Paget, and Valets~-the pasting away of the One Hundred
yeare, and a young Prince finding out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating
into the Palace—Ai> waking the Sleeping
Beauty, and all her Attendants—the
Princess and the Prince falling mutually m love at first tight, with the interference of
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who vows to do her worst to destroy their fiatipintss—the
arrival of one of the Fairy Godmothers of
the Princess to protect her—the constancy of the Prince being tried by the friendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all her arte and graces to turn him from the Princets—the
Prince becoming Harlequin, and the Princets following
him
through the world— the Spiteful Old t airy't resolve that the Prince and Princets shall not escape her, the changing
herself
•into Pantaloon, and one of her Familiars
into Clown—with the final triumph of the Prince and Princett,
who are made
happy by the Friendly
Fairy.

Fears, when a King's

Palace—her
slipping away from them, and finding an old woman spinning—her
trying to spin herself -her wounding her hand, as foretola, and falling
asleep for a hundred
Years—the friendly Fairy causing a Wood to grow up, and enclose the Palace, ana
the Princess sleeping for a Century / and with her, to keep her company, all the Maids of honour,
Gentlemen,
Officers,
Stewards, Cooks, Scullions, Running Footmen, Guards, Porters, Pages, and Valets—the pasting away of the One Hundred
fears, and a young Prince finding out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating
into the Palace—hit waking the Sleeping
Beauty, and all her Attendants—the
Princess and the Prince falling mutually in love at first sight, with the interference of
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who vows to do her worst to destroy their haiipiniss—the
arrival of one of the Fairy Godmothers of
the Princess to protect her—the constancy of the Prince being tried by the friendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all har arts and graces to turn him from the Princess—the
Prince becoming Harlequin,
and the Princess following him
through the world-- the Spiteful Old Fairy's resolve that the Prince and Princess shall not escape her, she changing
herself
into Pantaloon,
and one of her Familiars
into Clown—with the final triumph of the Prince and Princess, who are made
happy by the Friendly
Fairy.

mil embrace . . . the Incidents of the Story of " T H E S L E E P I N G B E A U T i iN T H E W O O D . "
The King and Qi.ee*
that lived once, and who had been married many yeais without having any children—the
beautiful Haby that wa* at latt
born to them—the Imitation
to all the Fairies t$ ttand Godmothers to the Princess at hrr Christening—the
unfortunate
emission of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old fairy,
who use supposed to he dead, or Under the influence of some sped—.
the good Gifts given to the young Princess hy Seven of her Fairy Godmothers—the
arriral of the Spiteful Fairy, who throws
the whole Court into dismay, by declaring that when the Princest grew to be a young unman she would prick her hand with
a spindle, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly
hairy, the principal
God mather, that she would so arrange
the matter that the Princess should not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only sleep a Hundred
Years, when a King's
Son would come and wake her — the Proclamation
issued by the King, abolishing; the use of spindles throughout the land—
the growing up of the Princess ttll she was sixteen—her
arr'nul with her Parents and the Court at a Summer
Palace—her
slipping W i t from them, and finding an old woman spinning,— her trying to spin herself -ho wounding her hand, as foretold, and falling asleep for a Hundred Vears— the friendly Fairy causing a 11 i,od to yrou up. a> d enclose the Palace, ana
the Princess sleeping jor a Century ; and with her, to keep her company, all the Maids if Honour, Gentlemen,
Officers,
Stewards, Cooks, HcuUions, Running Footmen, Guards, Porttrs, Pages, and Valets—the passing an ay of the One Hundred
i'eart, and a \,oung Prince fading out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating
into the Palace—his leaking the Sleeping
Beauty, and all her Attendants—the
Princess and the Prime lulling mutually in tore at first sight, with the interference of
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who rows to do her worst to rtestn m their hnppimss—the
urinal of one of the Fairy Godmothers of
the Princess to protect her—the lonslanco of the finite
being tried by the friendly fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all her arts anrt graces to turn him from the Pi nuess—the Prince hemming Harlequin, and the Princess following him
through the world— the Spiteful Old Fairy's tesolte that the Prince and Princess shall not escape her, she changing
herself
into Pantaloon,
and one of her Familiars
into Cloun—nith
i/.e final triumph of the Prince and Princess, who are made
happy by the Friendly
Fairy.

that lived once, and uho had keen married many yeare without having any children—the beautiful Baby that teas at loot
born to them—the Invitation to all the Fairiee to eland Godmoihere to the Prineeee at her Christening—the unfortunate
emission of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old Fairy, who woe supposed to be dead, or under the influence of lome iped-m
the good Giftt given to the young Princes* by Seven of her Fairy Godmother*—the arrival of the Spiteful Fairy, who throve
the whole Court into dismay, by declaring that when the frtneese grew to be a young woman she would prick her hand with
a spindle, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly Fairy, the principal Godmother, that she would so arrange
the matter that the Princess should not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only tleep a Hundred Yeare, when a A .«/«•
Son would come and wake her—the Proclamation issued by the Ktng, abolishing the use of epindles throughout the land—'
the growing up of the Princeee till she wae sixteen—her arrival with htr Parents and the Court at a Summer Palace—h*f
slipping away from thtm, and finding an old woman epinming— her trying to spin herself "her wounding her hand, as/orai
told, and falling asleep for a Hundred Ycaee—the friendly Fatry causing a Hood to grow up, and enclose the Palace, ana
the Princes* sleeping for a Century ; and uitk her, to keep her company, all the Malde of Honour, Gentlemen, Officers',
Stewards, Cooks, Scullions, Warning Footmen, Guards, Porters, Pagee, and Valets—the passing away of the One Hundred
Years, and a young Prince finding out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating into the Palace—hi* waking the Sleeping
Beauty, and all her Attendants—the Prinrese and Ike Prince Jailing mutually tn love at first sight, with the interference « /
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who row* to do her worst to destroy their ha*<ptn*ss—the arrival of one of the Fairy Gv<tmother* of
the Princess to protect her—the constancy of the Prime* being tried by the friendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
mil hot art* ana grace* to turn him trim the Prineets—tke Prince becoming Harlequin, and the Princess following him
through the world— the Sfiteful Old Fairy* tesolve that the Prince and Princets *hall not escape her, eke charging herself
into Pantaloon, and one of her Familiars MI/O Cloun—nith the final Ittimph of the Prince and Prince**, who are mad*
happy by the Friendly Fai*y, .

a spindie, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly Pairy, the principal
Godmother, that she would *o arrange
the matter that the Prim ess thould not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only deep a Hundred
Fears, when a King'*

trying to spin, herself -her wounding her hand, as foretola, and falling asleep for a Hundred Y' eart—the frtendly Fatry causing a IVnod to grow up, and enclose the Palace, ants

the Princess sleeping Jor a Century ; and uith her, to keep her company, all the Maid* of honour, Gentlemen, Officer*,

Fear*, and a toung Prince finding out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating into the Palace—his waking the Sleeping

THE COURT-YARD OF AN OLO ENGLISH MANSION ON CHRISTMAS NICHT.

„ Hunning
Years, and a young Prince finding out the Wood, while hunting, and penetrating
into the Palace—his waking the Sleeping
Beauty, and all her Attendants—the
Princess and the Prince tolling mutually \n love at first sight, with the interference of
the Spiteful Old Fairy, who vows to do her worst to destroy their hajmntss—the
arrival of one of the Fairy Godmother* of
tie Princess to protect her—the constancy of the Prince being tried by the friendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all her arts and graces to turn him from the Princess—the Prince becoming Harlequin, and the Princess following km
through the uorld— the Spiteful Old Fairy's resolve that the Prince and Prineea shall not escape her, she changing
herself
into Pantaloon, and one of her Familiars
into Cloitn—with the final Irttrnph of the Prince and Princess, who are made
happy by the Friendly Fairy,

WILLIAM

HARLEQUINADE.

P O L K A P A S T O R A L E , by Mr. ARTHUR LECLERCQ and Miss FANNY WRIGHT.

L E C L E R C Q.

mil embrace all the Incident* of the Story of " T H E S L E E P I N G B E A U T Y I N T H E W O O D . " The King and Queen
that lived once, and who had been married many year* without having any children—the beautiful Baby that was at last
born to them—the Invitation to all the Fairtes to stand Godmothert to the Princess at her Christening—the
unfort una >
omietion of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old Fairy, who was supposed to be dead, or under the influence of some sped—
the good Gifts given to the young Princess by Seven of her Fairy Godmothers—the arrival of the Spiteful Fairy, who throu«
the whole Court into dismay, by declaring that when the Princess grew to be a young woman she would prick her hand wun
a spindle, and die of the wound—the rejoinder of a friendly Fairy, the principal Godmother, that she would so arrange
the matter that the Princess should not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only deep a Hundred Years, when a Kino's
Son would come and wake her—the Proclamation issued by the Ktng, abolishing the use of spindles throughout the land—
the growing up of the Princess till she was sixteen—her arrival with her Parents and the Court at a Summer
Palace—

Ir.

A « !>

ft

*

OF THE

'The SCENERY of ihe OPENING STORY painted by

TOT
p i N r r « mm m mm B
. BS
mil embrace all the Incident* of the Story of "THE SLFEPING BEAUTY IN THE WOOD," The King and Qu,,n
that lived once, and who had been married many years without having any children—the beautiful Baby that was at last
born to thtm—the Invitation to all the Fatrie* to itand Godmothers to the Princess at her Christening—the unfortumiia
omission of neglecting to invite a Spiteful Old Fairy, who was supposed to he dead, or under the influence of some speU—
the good Gifts giten to the young Princess by Seven of her Fairy Godmothers—the arrival of the Spiteful Fairy, who throw*
the whole Court into dismay, by declaring that when the Princess grew to be a young woman she would prick her hand wM
a spindle, and die of the wound— the rejoinder of a friendly Fairy, the principal Godmother, that she would so arrange
the matter that the Princess should not die, when wounded by the spindle, but only sleep a Hundred Years, when a King's
Son would come and wake her—the Proclamation issued by the King, abolishing the use of spindles throughout the land—the growing uj< of the Princess till she was sixteen—her arrival with her Parents and the Court at a Summer Palace—Air
sliming away from them, and finding art old woman spinning— her trying to spin herself -her wounding her hand, a* for*.
old, and jailing asleep for a Hundred Years-the friendly fairy causing a Hood to grow up. and enclose the- Palace, ana,
the Princess sleeping for a Century; and with her, to keep her company, all the Maids of Honour, Gentlemen, Officers,
Stewards, Cook/, Scullions, Punning Footmen, Guards, Porters, Pages, and Vaiets—the pasting away of the One Hundred
Years, and a young Prince finding out the Wood, uhik hunting, and penetrating into the Palaos—his waking the i
lore at first sight, with th« interference of
art ival of one of ike Fairy Godmothers of
to protect her—toe constancy of me rrtnee oetng inea uy tne jnendly Fairy becoming Columbine, and using
all htr arts ana graces to turn him from the Princess—the Prince becoming Harlequin, and the Princess following hum
through the world— the Sfxteful Old Fairy's resolve that the Prince and Princess shall not escapt htr, she changing herself
into Pantaloon, and cne of her Familiars into Clown—with the final triumph of the frince and Princess, who are mads
happy by the Friendly Fairy.

S.

LORD DUNDREARY
EVERT

EVENING!

MR. SOTHERN.
The great originality and extraordinary humour of Mr. SOTH.ER.N'S
representation of LORD DUNDREARY having greatly attracted
the Public and called forth the unanimous approval of the Press,
while the reading of " B r o t h e r Sam's Letter M is still producing
the unusual honor of a Nightly Encore, this Performance will be
repeated Every Evening.
Opinions of the Press on this remarkable Performance.
" Such It the genii)* of Mr. Sothern. that every one who sees him feels that an old type to presented
with Individual peculiar 1 tie. that render It a complete novelty. Who ever heard before of a letter read
aloud nn the -tare being encored like a song )"—Vitte Time*. " Mr. ftotheni't smallest gesturus aro
till of comic expression In the reading of ' llrotber Sam's' letter be In every nigbt. enthusiastically
encored | compliment usually reserved foT vocalists, but now, fbr the first time, bestowed npon a
comedian "—Homing Post. " Mr. Sot hern's Impersonation of Lord Dundreary will probably become
a favourite topic of conversation, and will draw crowds of all classes to the theatre.-'—-Patty New*.
" It la a creation which evidences very high dramatic appreciation on the part of the actor Every
look, every gesture, every movement, Is in harmony, and all are remarkably truthful and ludicrous."—
Daily Ttltgrapk. " It was, from beginning to end, a triumph of the ludicrous -"—Morning Star.
*' His success Is enormous, but tt is not greater than his deserts." — 8atur>*ay Review. "They who
wish to see a new type of a swell, quite different from any that the stage has showed them, should go
and have a laugh at Mr. Sotbern's Lord Dundreary.' ~/'imeA " Wt never witnessed a sneeeaa which
was more Immediate or more deserved | he fairly toe* the house by stotm''~.Dt>patcA. " Mr. Bother"
(who. by the way. Is an Englishman) performs with such admirable and original humour, that the
wilderness of the- conception is forgiven "—Lloyd* Weekly Newt. '* Mr. Sethem Is so Impertnbably
extravagant that shouts of laughter follow almost every look and gesture. He contrives, iu the mldat
of all the extravagance, to maintain lor his Inane lord the air of a well-bred gentleman.'— Examiner
